title: Workers Exposed to Harmful Chemicals in Firefighting Foam
summary: A factory in Swansea, Wales, had workers who were exposed to dangerous chemicals for many years. The factory, owned by a big company called 3M, made things like nappy fastenings and video tapes. Some workers were part of a 'fire party' team that practiced putting out fires using a special foam. This foam contained toxic chemicals called PFOS and PFOA, which can cause cancer and stay in the environment forever. The company knew about the risks but did not tell the workers. The factory is now closed, and the site is polluted with these chemicals from old firefighting activities. The BBC found documents showing the contamination, and workers are sharing their stories for the first time.

background_read: This article is about a factory in Wales where workers were exposed to dangerous chemicals without knowing it. The chemicals, called PFOS and PFOA, are part of firefighting foam and can cause cancer. The company 3M owned the factory and did not warn the workers, even though they knew the risks. The factory is now closed, but the land is still dirty with these chemicals. The BBC found out about this by looking at documents and talking to workers who were part of a firefighting team.
